content: Good Morning America how are you? More large companies are putting a freeze on pensions. Found this one on the front page of USA Today. The number of companies that have frozen their traditional pension plans has accelerated sharply this year, a trend that will likely continue as companies wrestle with declining profits and poor investment returns. At least 16 companies have announced plans to freeze their pensions so far this year, vs. 18 for all of 2008. Last week, Wells Fargo told its employees that their pension plans will stop accruing benefits July 1. When a pension is frozen, employees get to keep the benefits they've already earned, but the company usually won't contribute any more money. Older employees are particularly hard hit because they have less time to make up for the loss, says Nancy Hwa, spokeswoman for the Pension Rights Center. Severe investment losses in 2008 shrank the assets of the nation's largest pension plans to 79% of projected liabilities, down from 109% at the end of 2007, according to an analysis by Watson Wyatt. Companies, already hurting in the weak economy, have to increase contributions to make up the difference, and are facing stricter federal requirements about funding the plans. More companies will freeze their pension plans unless Congress temporarily relaxes the funding requirements, says Dena Battle, director of tax policy for the National Association of Manufacturers. "When your funding obligations triple and you don't have the cash to deal with that and you don't get relief from Congress, you have to make hard choices," she says. FIND MORE STORIES IN: United States House of Representatives | Wells Fargo | National Association of Manufacturers | Watson Wyatt Worldwide Pension-rights advocates and some lawmakers support giving relief only to companies that agree not to freeze their plans. "Congress will be hesitant to provide pension fund relief without assurance that employers would protect benefits of rank-and-file employees and not divert funding relief to other uses," such as corporate bonuses, says Sandra Salstrom, a spokeswoman for Rep. Earl Pomeroy, D-N.D., who is drafting a pension relief bill. Battle says many plan sponsors would reject relief on those terms. The employer-sponsored retirement system, "has always been voluntary," she says. "We work very hard to preserve that."

"Congress will be hesitant to provide pension fund relief without assurance that employers would protect benefits of rank-and-file employees and not divert funding relief to other uses," such as corporate bonuses, says Sandra Salstrom, a spokeswoman for Rep. Earl Pomeroy, D-N.D., who is drafting a pension relief bill. Battle says many plan sponsors would reject relief on those terms. The employer-sponsored retirement system, "has always been voluntary," she says. "We work very hard to preserve that."
title: How do you all like the new change and hope now?

title: How do you all like the new change and hope now?

content: quote: More companies will freeze their pension plans unless Congress temporarily relaxes the funding requirements In other words, the companies want to return to the "good ol' days" when they were allowed to deliberately underfund their pension liabilities with the promise that it would be there when it was needed. They've been allowed to get away with that scam since the Reagan era. Now, not suprisingly, when it's time to pay up, they don't have the money. Gee, who coulda seen that coming? But, don't worry...their bought and paid for toadies in Congress have already dealt with that problem: They'll shift their pension liabilities off on YOU, Mr and Mrs Taxpayer, via the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation and you retirees will be lucky to get 50 cents on the dollar.

content: What I think we've lost sight of is that a guaranteed retirement is nowhere in the constitution. from the gov't side it's a self-repeating ponzi,from the corporate side it's a way to attract recruits.. no more, no less.. when you invest your SSI taxes with the gov't, or your time and energy with a company, you need to handle it as you would any other investment: returns may vary and carry a significant possibility of loss.

title: How do you all like the new change and hope now?

content: quote: Originally posted by godawgz: What I think we've lost sight of is that a guaranteed retirement is nowhere in the constitution. from the gov't side it's a self-repeating ponzi,from the corporate side it's a way to attract recruits.. no more, no less.. when you invest your SSI taxes with the gov't, or your time and energy with a company, you need to handle it as you would any other investment: returns may vary and carry a significant possibility of loss. That's all well and good, but they should have to TELL you that. Loud and clear. So far, that kind of transparency just ain't around. When I first got hired in 1974, I was overwhelmed with the impression that I didn't have to worry my little head about anything, cuz I worked for this awesome company who was taking care of ALL that. Within a couple of decades, without feeling too obliged to explain much or justify their actions, we went from having a defined benefit plan, to an ESOP hybrid (100% company stock, of course); but, with a separate 401k thrown in, for good measure. But the 401k, of course, was "just for fun". It was just something in there to make our already cool pension.... even nicer. Nobody ever explained to us that we might have to rely on the 401k savings exclusively, or that company stock could drop from $70 a share to $6 in a few month's time. In fact, we were even told that the ups and downs of the stock market would affect our pensions... not at all. Guess they had some magical way of doing that. Only a bad employee would question it. I still have the company propaganda tucked away somewhere in my files, just to reassure myself that I didn't make that up. So since they didn't seem to take it seriously, neither did I. I kind of wish now I had ignored them all, and just put my money in a regular passbook savings. By the time you lose your a$$ ten times in your 401k and finally get it all back... are you getting ahead? When the market is up, it's fun, but it’s sort of a fool’s paradise.

But the 401k, of course, was "just for fun". It was just something in there to make our already cool pension.... even nicer. Nobody ever explained to us that we might have to rely on the 401k savings exclusively, or that company stock could drop from $70 a share to $6 in a few month's time. In fact, we were even told that the ups and downs of the stock market would affect our pensions... not at all. Guess they had some magical way of doing that. Only a bad employee would question it. I still have the company propaganda tucked away somewhere in my files, just to reassure myself that I didn't make that up. So since they didn't seem to take it seriously, neither did I. I kind of wish now I had ignored them all, and just put my money in a regular passbook savings. By the time you lose your a$$ ten times in your 401k and finally get it all back... are you getting ahead? When the market is up, it's fun, but it’s sort of a fool’s paradise.

content: I don't drink and I've never done drugs and I've given up gambling and gave up cigarettes. The other night I stepped outside and suddenly saw a bright light shining down on me. content: Chuckles, continued ~ Thanks for the 'minder. Yup, more money for Al Gore and his cheat minded sumb!t@hes. break, break What me worry? No. But, yes, my yard, once upon a time, was investigated by air---3x by 3 different A/C, all in 2 days: one was a black helo, another was by a low flying monoplane 50' above the ground (illegal if i flew like that!), inbetwixt 2 Doug Fir tree lines. Speaking of Marine KC-130s, Henry (Bud) Wildfang, USMC C-130 pilot emeritus, awardee of the Navy's Gray Eagle Trophy: “The Venerable Order of the Gray Eagle. The Most Ancient Naval Aviator on Active Duty. In recognition of a clear eye, a stout heart, a steady hand, and a daring defiance of gravity and the law of averages.” ..has the most flight hours of any of us transporters. He turns 93 this month. There's still hope, given all this Obama, Bush (et al [illuminati?]) crap. His mother died a couple of years ago at 107. He, too is from North Dakota. Where if you die in winter, you must hang around a little longer to be buried---after spring thaw when digging is easier than pounding rock.

content: Wonder how Pelosi and "the gang" are going to get the retirement taxes from the people that got screwed on their pensions? I guess the illegals will be supported by yet "another" tax created by Congress or Gore. With the Civil Service program, expected to reach over 3 million, and the Civil Defense Force being increased another 75 thousand...the money has to come from somewhere. We are paying for our own police state, at the expense of protecting the crooks in Washington. They plan on increasing taxes on retirement, and have the gall to reinstate the death tax.

content: What I think we've lost sight of is that a guaranteed retirement is nowhere in the constitution. from the gov't side it's a self-repeating ponzi,from the corporate side it's a way to attract recruits.. no more, no less.. when you invest your SSI taxes with the gov't, or your time and energy with a company, you need to handle it as you would any other investment: returns may vary and carry a significant possibility of loss.

No savings this year---maybe never again in IRAs ..probably never more from me in any place the government can see and find.

title: How do you all like the new change and hope now?

content: quote: Originally posted by godawgz: What I think we've lost sight of is that a guaranteed retirement is nowhere in the constitution. from the gov't side it's a self-repeating ponzi,from the corporate side it's a way to attract recruits.. no more, no less.. when you invest your SSI taxes with the gov't, or your time and energy with a company, you need to handle it as you would any other investment: returns may vary and carry a significant possibility of loss. That's all well and good, but they should have to TELL you that. Loud and clear. So far, that kind of transparency just ain't around. When I first got hired in 1974, I was overwhelmed with the impression that I didn't have to worry my little head about anything, cuz I worked for this awesome company who was taking care of ALL that. Within a couple of decades, without feeling too obliged to explain much or justify their actions, we went from having a defined benefit plan, to an ESOP hybrid (100% company stock, of course); but, with a separate 401k thrown in, for good measure. But the 401k, of course, was "just for fun". It was just something in there to make our already cool pension.... even nicer. Nobody ever explained to us that we might have to rely on the 401k savings exclusively, or that company stock could drop from $70 a share to $6 in a few month's time. In fact, we were even told that the ups and downs of the stock market would affect our pensions... not at all. Guess they had some magical way of doing that. Only a bad employee would question it. I still have the company propaganda tucked away somewhere in my files, just to reassure myself that I didn't make that up. So since they didn't seem to take it seriously, neither did I. I kind of wish now I had ignored them all, and just put my money in a regular passbook savings. By the time you lose your a$$ ten times in your 401k and finally get it all back... are you getting ahead? When the market is up, it's fun, but it’s sort of a fool’s paradise.
quote: Originally posted by godawgz: What I think we've lost sight of is that a guaranteed retirement is nowhere in the constitution. from the gov't side it's a self-repeating ponzi,from the corporate side it's a way to attract recruits.. no more, no less.. when you invest your SSI taxes with the gov't, or your time and energy with a company, you need to handle it as you would any other investment: returns may vary and carry a significant possibility of loss.
reply: That's all well and good, but they should have to TELL you that. Loud and clear. So far, that kind of transparency just ain't around. When I first got hired in 1974, I was overwhelmed with the impression that I didn't have to worry my little head about anything, cuz I worked for this awesome company who was taking care of ALL that. Within a couple of decades, without feeling too obliged to explain much or justify their actions, we went from having a defined benefit plan, to an ESOP hybrid (100% company stock, of course); but, with a separate 401k thrown in, for good measure. But the 401k, of course, was "just for fun". It was just something in there to make our already cool pension.... even nicer. Nobody ever explained to us that we might have to rely on the 401k savings exclusively, or that company stock could drop from $70 a share to $6 in a few month's time. In fact, we were even told that the ups and downs of the stock market would affect our pensions... not at all. Guess they had some magical way of doing that. Only a bad employee would question it. I still have the company propaganda tucked away somewhere in my files, just to reassure myself that I didn't make that up. So since they didn't seem to take it seriously, neither did I. I kind of wish now I had ignored them all, and just put my money in a regular passbook savings. By the time you lose your a$$ ten times in your 401k and finally get it all back... are you getting ahead? When the market is up, it's fun, but it’s sort of a fool’s paradise.

content: Firewood is still a good investment. In the early seventies it cost $50.00/cord, cut and delivered. Today, almost 40 years later (what a deal!) only $125.00 per. My current supply will keep me and my babe in heat for the next 5 years.

content: I don't drink and I've never done drugs and I've given up gambling and gave up cigarettes. The other night I stepped outside and suddenly saw a bright light shining down on me. I thought, maybe I'm being taken up in Heaven, but then I remembered I have a motion detector light. That's what has changed. I forget things. Everything else still sucks.

content: Chuckles, continued ~ Thanks for the 'minder. Yup, more money for Al Gore and his cheat minded sumb!t@hes. break, break What me worry? No. But, yes, my yard, once upon a time, was investigated by air---3x by 3 different A/C, all in 2 days: one was a black helo, another was by a low flying monoplane 50' above the ground (illegal if i flew like that!), inbetwixt 2 Doug Fir tree lines. Speaking of Marine KC-130s, Henry (Bud) Wildfang, USMC C-130 pilot emeritus, awardee of the Navy's Gray Eagle Trophy: “The Venerable Order of the Gray Eagle. The Most Ancient Naval Aviator on Active Duty. In recognition of a clear eye, a stout heart, a steady hand, and a daring defiance of gravity and the law of averages.” ..has the most flight hours of any of us transporters. He turns 93 this month. There's still hope, given all this Obama, Bush (et al [illuminati?]) crap. His mother died a couple of years ago at 107. He, too is from North Dakota. Where if you die in winter, you must hang around a little longer to be buried---after spring thaw when digging is easier than pounding rock.
